qas.question: What is also captured by plants as chemical potential energy in photosynthesis?
What do plants release during photosynthesis?
What may be triggered suddenly by a spark?

answers.text: Release of the energy stored during photosynthesis

qas.question: What isn't captured by plants as chemical potential energy in photosynthesis?
What do plants retain? during photosynthesis?

plausible_answers.text: Release of the energy stored during photosynthesis

qas.question: What may be triggered after a long time by a spark?
what is utilized by dead organisms as an electron acceptor?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>Sunlight<b4_0/><a0_0/> is also captured by plants as chemical potential energy in photosynthesis, when <a3_0><b7_0>carbon dioxide and water<b7_0/><a3_0/> (two low-energy compounds) are converted into the high-energy compounds carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins. Plants also release <a1_0><b5_0><b8_0>oxygen<b8_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/> during photosynthesis, which is utilized by living organisms as an electron acceptor, to release the energy of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins. <a2_0><b6_0>Release of the energy stored during photosynthesis<b6_0/><a2_0/> as heat or light may be triggered suddenly by a spark, in a forest fire, or it may be made available more slowly for animal or human metabolism, when these molecules are ingested, and catabolism is triggered by enzyme action.
